dt: {bc}a book containing accounts to which debits and credits are posted from books of original entry

dt.t: Psmith, perched gracefully on a stool, entered figures in a {wi}ledger{/wi}.

dt: {bc}a digital record that is used similarly to an accounting ledger (as for maintaining a list of transactions)

dt.t: Williams said he also recovered a {wi}ledger{/wi} spreadsheet on a laptop computer seized from Wright and a "key" to translate the {wi}ledger{/wi}.
NFTs use blockchain, the technology {wi}ledger{/wi} backing cryptocurrencies …, which are databases of linked information to record ownership or transactions of a product.

The original idea behind Provenance was to provide transparency, proof of loan performance, provenance—reliable information about who owned or owns an asset at any given time—lower costs and easier audits for loan buyers and sellers through distributed {wi}ledger{/wi} technology.

dt: {bc}a horizontal board used for vertical support (as in scaffolding)

dt.t: I'd rather see joists resting on a {wi}ledger{/wi}, spiked to the girders or to the house through spacers.

et: Middle English {it}lygger, leger{/it} large breviary, beam, probably from {it}leyen, leggen{/it} to lay
